Introduction

Cyclothymic disorder is a chronic mood disorder characterized by alternating depressive and hypomanic symptoms that are insufficient in number, severity, and/or duration to meet the full criteria for a major depressive or hypomanic episode.  Mood symptoms must be present for at least half of a 2-year period (1 year in children).  The frequent and unpredictable mood changes cause significant functional impairment.

Epidemiology



The lifetime prevalence of cyclothymic disorder is ~0.5%-1%.  Prevalence rates are similar in males and females, and onset is typically during adolescence or early adulthood.

Clinical presentation



Cyclothymic disorder is characterized by alternating hypomanic and depressive symptoms that occur for at least half of a 2-year period (1 year in children).  The symptoms must not meet criteria for a major mood episode (hypomanic or major depressive episode) and may present as insufficient symptom number (eg, only 2 hypomanic symptoms) or duration (eg, 1 week of depressive symptoms).



Mood symptoms are usually spontaneous and not in response to an external event or stressor.  Some patients may appear to randomly shift from being self-confident to insecure, outgoing to withdrawn, and/or energetic to slowed down.  Initial presentation may be due to "moodiness" or "unpredictability" or for evaluation of common comorbidities such as anxiety disorders or attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

Hypomanic symptoms 



Patients may be uncharacteristically enthusiastic and euphoric, though mood can shift rapidly to irritable or angry.  They may exhibit increased activity levels and energy and often initiate multiple new tasks or projects; this can be associated with an improvement in functioning for some.  Additional symptoms may include:



  • Distractibility:  results in difficulty focusing, following directions, and conversing; patients are unable to filter out irrelevant external stimuli.
  • Impulsivity (excessive involvement in activities with high potential for painful consequences):  can include uncharacteristic gambling, shopping sprees, reckless driving, and/or risky sexual behaviors due to impaired judgment.
  • Grandiosity or inflated self-esteem:  can include high levels of self-confidence in areas with which the patient has no experience (eg, providing legal advice despite no knowledge of the law) or grandiose delusions (eg, believing they have superhuman powers or a special relationship with a religious figure).
  • Flight of ideas or racing thoughts:  make it difficult to communicate clearly; patient responses are irrelevant to questions and may jump from topic to topic.
  • Activity increased (including goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation):  may appear as engaging in multiple different activities (eg, projects at work, sex, participation in religious or political causes, increased social contact); patients may also appear to be restless (eg, pacing, fidgeting).
  • Sleep decreased:  very common; patients may not sleep at all or sleep 2-3 hours a night and feel well rested; this differs from insomnia, which occurs when a patient feels tired and wants to sleep but cannot.
  • Talkativeness (more talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking):  includes rapid speech that is difficult to interrupt; speech is often loud and may include jokes, singing, laughter, or threats.

Depressive symptoms



  • Low mood:  can be described by a patient in different ways (eg, down, empty, sad, hopeless) or can be observed (eg, frequent tearfulness); irritability instead of sadness is common in children and adolescents.
  • Decreased interest or pleasure in activities (anhedonia):  may be experienced as not participating or caring about previously enjoyed hobbies/activities; can include social withdrawal (eg, no longer attending family events) and decreased interest in sex.
  • Weight or appetite changes:  vary and can either increase (eg, cravings for carbohydrates with resulting weight gain) or decrease (eg, skipping meals and losing weight).
  • Sleep changes:  can include hypersomnia (increased nighttime sleeping and/or daytime naps) or difficulty sleeping (most commonly nighttime awakening with difficulty falling back to sleep).
  • Psychomotor changes:  present as either restlessness (eg, pacing, hand-wringing, fidgeting) or retardation (eg, slow thinking and body movements, increased speech latency).
  • Fatigue or decreased energy:  very common in depression; everyday tasks that require minimal exertion are exhausting (eg, checking mail, brushing teeth).
  • Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt:  can include negative self-evaluation and feelings of guilt for minor past failings (eg, accidentally denting the car years ago); thoughts can be delusional (eg, believing one is the sole cause of climate change).
  • Concentration difficulties or indecisiveness:  can include easy distractibility, memory issues, or difficulty making minor decisions (eg, what to wear); may manifest as poor performance at work or school.
  • Thoughts of death, suicidal ideation, or suicide attempt:  ranges from passive thoughts of suicide (eg, not wanting to be alive anymore, being better off dead) to thoughts about killing oneself with a specific plan, to acting on suicidal thoughts.

Diagnosis



For a diagnosis of cyclothymic disorder, the following criteria must be met:



  • For at least 2 years (at least 1 year in children and adolescents), the individual has numerous periods with hypomanic symptoms that do not meet criteria for a hypomanic episode and numerous periods with depressive symptoms that do not meet criteria for a major depressive episode.
  • During this 2-year period (1 year in children and adolescents), symptoms have been present for at least half the time and the individual has not been without the symptoms for more than 2 months at a time.
  • Symptoms are not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum or other psychotic disorders.  In addition, symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (eg, drug of abuse, medication) or another medical condition (eg, hyperthyroidism).

Differential diagnosis



When considering the differential diagnosis for mood instability, the duration and severity of symptoms and history of major mood episodes are distinguishing factors (

):



  • Bipolar I disorder:  characterized by at least 1 manic episode lasting at least 1 week.
  • Bipolar II disorder:  must include at least 1 hypomanic episode and at least 1 major depressive episode.
  • Major depressive disorder:  involves at least 2 weeks of low mood and/or anhedonia with additional depressive symptoms resulting in functional impairment; not associated with periods of hypomania.
  • Borderline personality disorder (BPD):  also involves abrupt shifts in mood and impulsivity; however, symptoms are typically in response to interpersonal stressors (not spontaneous), and additional hypomanic symptoms, such as elation and increased energy, are not typical of BPD.  BPD can co-occur with cyclothymic disorder, in which case both diagnoses would be given.

Evaluation and diagnostic work-up



A thorough history, including prior mood episodes, substance use, and family psychiatric disorders, as well as physical examination are necessary to determine the likelihood of cyclothymic disorder versus other medical/psychiatric conditions with similar presentations.



Initial laboratory testing should include complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, serum TSH level, and urine drug screen.  Depending on clinical findings, additional diagnostic work-up may be indicated for conditions that can present with fluctuating mood symptoms (eg, hypercortisolism, epilepsy, multiple sclerosis).

Management



Cyclothymic disorder, with its associated mood instability and impulsivity, is associated with an increased risk for suicidal behavior.  Screening for suicidal ideation (

), and safety planning are necessary for all patients.  Suicide risk often determines the appropriate level of care; patients at imminent risk of harming themselves (eg, suicidal ideation with a plan and intent) require emergency hospitalization.



The management of cyclothymic disorder primarily involves psychotherapy, lifestyle modifications, and, for more severe symptoms or functional impairment, pharmacotherapy:



  • Psychotherapy:  Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) identifies and reframes negative thought patterns and develops more adaptive ways of coping with stressors.  Interpersonal psychotherapy (IPT) is appropriate when a specific life situation is contributing to symptoms (eg, estrangement, grief, postpartum period); examines interpersonal conflict and effects on emotions.
  • Lifestyle modifications may reduce the risk of relapse.  Areas in which healthy habits should be maintained include sleep hygiene, physical exercise, balanced diet, and avoidance of recreational substance use.
  • Pharmacotherapy is limited because there are no FDA-approved options for cyclothymic disorder.  For severe symptoms, patients may benefit from mood stabilizers (eg, lithium, valproate, carbamazepine, lamotrigine) or second-generation antipsychotics (eg, quetiapine).  However, monotherapy with antidepressants is avoided to prevent mood switching and rapid cycling.


Cyclothymic disorder commonly co-occurs with ADHD, anxiety disorders, and sleep disorders (difficulty initiating and maintaining sleep) as well as substance use and eating disorders; screening and treatment are indicated.

Prognosis



Cyclothymic disorder has a variable prognosis.  Though symptoms are considered less severe than bipolar disorder, the social and occupational impairment from frequent mood instability and inconsistency can be significant.  A minority of patients initially diagnosed with cyclothymic disorder will ultimately develop bipolar I or II disorder, most often during adolescence or young adulthood.

Summary



Cyclothymic disorder is a chronic mood disorder characterized by alternating depressive and hypomanic symptoms that are insufficient in number, severity, and/or duration to meet full criteria for a major depressive or hypomanic episode.  Mood symptoms must be present for at least half of a 2-year period (1 year in children).  Treatment primarily consists of psychotherapy and lifestyle modifications, though mood stabilizers may be considered for severe symptoms.
